Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Discovery and Design of Magnetic Alloys by Simulation and Experiment

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Magnetic cooling, in which a magnetic field is used to change the temperature of a material, offers a profoundly different energy solution to applications involving power generation, heating, and refrigeration. Magnetic cooling is potentially an environmentally friendly, energy-efficient technology capable of outperforming conventional gas-compression refrigeration. It has been over fifteen years since the discovery of materials that can convert magnetism for cooling in normal operating conditions, but much is still unknown about how to optimize the manufacture and performance of these materials. This Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) project seeks to identify and optimize the chemical compositions of magnetic alloys, and understand the fundamental scientific properties that control this important behavior. A combined computational and experimental design approach will be used to identify the optimal candidate systems rapidly. Advanced computational methods will be used to predict and design alloys exhibiting the strongest effect; the most promising compositions discovered will then be synthesized and tested in the laboratory. The expected results are (i) the identification of several high-performance magnetic alloys for cooling and refrigeration, and (ii) an assessment of the performance attainable in this highly promising class of materials.

This program focuses on optimizing performance within one of the most promising class of materials: the metamagnetic Ni-Mn-Sn and Ni-Mn-In-(Co) shape memory alloys. Due to a unique coupling between two design degrees of freedom, magnetism and crystal structure, these Heusler-type alloys have the potential to dramatically change our approach to cooling and refrigeration. This effort brings a combined computational/experimental methodology to design and optimization, via quantum mechanical simulation methods and unique experimental capabilities to measure performance under large magnetic fields. A set of target performance metrics, elastic constants, phonon modes, spin wave stiffnesses, and exchange interaction energies - will be calculated using quantum mechanical models coupled with phenomenological descriptions. For the most promising candidates, targeted experiments on single crystal samples will be used to validate the computational models by studying the magnetic field induced transition from the martensite phase to the austenite phase in selected compositions producing a significant change in magnetization. Ultimately this program will provide an exhaustive assessment across a spectrum of candidates in the metamagnetic shape memory alloys Ni-Mn-Sn and Ni-Mn-In-(Co).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.  Magneto and elasto -caloric shape memory alloys are of interest in emerging, solid state approaches to cooling and refrigeration. Historically, the identification of high performance, durable shape memory alloys has been hindered by a lack of fundamental understanding and the need for laborious trial and error based approaches to optimizing alloy compositions. The performance of a given alloy is extremely sensitive to its composition, and compositions must be optimized to achieve high-performance, durable materials. The primary goal of this program has been to establish an experimentally-validated computational framework for rapidly predicting, designing, and optimizing the performance of ferromagnetic shape memory alloys exhibiting the magnetocaloric effect to accelerate this process. This program utilized a computational and experimental approach to identify the key factors that affect shape memory alloy performance. A new computational approach was developed that predicts critical shape memory alloy properties such as transformation temperatures and entropy changes as a function of alloy composition. The approach combines quantum mechanical modeling, machine learning, and statistical mechanics and has been developed for the promising Heusler structure shape memory materials. To date, the approach has been validated on several Heusler structure shape memory alloy families. In experiment, this program supported a comprehensive assessment of the elastocaloric response of a large class of shape memory alloys. Several factors affecting alloy performance were characterized, such as alloy fatigue resistance and the temperature window of the stress-induced phase transformation. The program has led to several new fundamental insights into design principles to optimize shape memory alloy performance, which may enable more rapid discovery and identification high performance, durable materials in the future. 

Broader Impact. Shape memory alloys are important across a variety of emerging technologies and applications that rely on generation of force or motion, such as for passive damping against earthquake resistance, actuators activated by current-induced temperature changes, and stents that prop arteries open by deploying at body temperature.  Enhancement of the magnetocaloric performance in shape memory alloys offers the possibility of solid-state approach to cooling and refrigeration that can be a green, efficient alternative to conventional vapor compression refrigeration without the use of high global warming potential compounds. This program has resulted in the development of an open source computational platform to predict and optimize the composition-dependent properties of these alloys. The results of this program have been disseminated through archival journal publications and through invited and contributed conference presentations and seminars. In addition, this program has supported the several outreach activities over the course of its duration: high school students interested in studying engineering have participated in weeklong summer camps where they learned about and carried out design activities using shape memory alloys. Several workshops to undergraduate and graduate students were offered, focusing on computational and data-driven approaches to materials design and discovery, highlighting shape memory alloys as an example design space.
